frontmatter.title: Unsupervised Particle Picking
supervisors: Mostofa Rafid Uddin (Graduate Research Assistant, Carnegie Mellon University) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=csnAp98AAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao

node.html:
Currently working on developing a novel method for particle picking from macromolecular samples.

Status : In Progress

frontmatter.title: Automated Analysis of Parkinson’s Disease with Remote Tasks
supervisors: Dr. Mohammad Saifur Rahman (Associate Professor, BUET) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=9d52x-cAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao
colabs: Dr. Ehsan Hoque (Associate Professor, University of Rochester) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=ZJrR0KQAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao
Md. Saiful Islam (Graduate Research Assistant, University of Rochester) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=LmRLizgAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao

node.html:
Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a degenerative brain disorder that is usually observed among elderly people with symptoms like shaking, slowness and stiffness, difficulty with walking and balance.

In general neurologists examine PD suspect patients where the patients are asked to perform some motor neuron tasks. The research goal of this project is to use computer vision techniques to do this diagnosis remotely using a simple automated online screening tool. In developing countries like Bangladesh, neurologists are scarce compared to the number of patients and a tool like this will enable people to get timely diagnosis and subsequent healthcare.

Status : Manuscript in preparation.

frontmatter.title: Quartet Fiduccia-Mattheyses Revisited for Larger Phylogenetic Studies
supervisors: Dr. Mohammad Saifur Rahman (Associate Professor, BUET) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=9d52x-cAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao
Dr. Md Shamsuzzoha Bayzid (Associate Professor, BUET) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=h2vHz3wAAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao

node.html:
QFM-FI, a faster and improved version of the Quartet Fiduccia and Mattheyses algorithm, has been devised to enable its use in large-scale phylogeny estimation. The enhanced version achieves a speedup of 20,000x compared to its predecessor and 400x when compared with the widely utilized variant of QFM implemented in PAUP*. Furthermore, a comparative study was conducted on both simulated and actual biological datasets to evaluate the performance of QFM-FI with state-of-the-art methods. The study exhibited that QFM-FI outperforms QFM with regards to running time and tree quality while producing trees that are comparable to state-of-the-art methods. A theoretical analysis of the running time and memory requirements of QFM and QFM-FI were also provided for better comparison.

Status : Accepted at Bioinformatics Journal!

We created the first Bangla Plagiarism Dataset (Available in Hugging Face). Along with that, we proposed two distinct approaches for detecting plagiarism. The first method involves fine-tuning Bangla BERT, while the second method utilizes sentence embeddings for multi-document plagiarism detection. Code and Preprint will soon be available.

frontmatter.title: Occam's Razor Strikes Again: Revisiting Short-Text Stream Clustering with Latest Sentence Embeddings
supervisors: Dr. Shubhra Kanti Karmaker (Assistant Professor, Auburn University) || https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=y6pZKT4AAAAJ&hl=en&oi=ao

node.html: Contributed to the development of a novel software tool called One Pass Sentence Embedding Clustering (OPSEC) as part of a team. The tool efficiently clusters short text streams using a unique one-pass algorithm that calculates similarity scores based on sentence embeddings. OPSEC outperforms current state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and quality of clustering for short text streams.

Sign language, as a different form of communication language, is important to large groups of people in society. Each sign in sign language is unique due to variations in hand form, motion profile, and positioning of the hand, face, and other body components. So, visual sign language recognition is a complex research area in computer vision. In this work, we present a new word-level Bangla Sign Language (BdSL) dataset consisting of 611 videos over 40 BdSL words, along with two different approaches: one with a 3D Convolutional Neural Network model and another a novel Graph Neural Network based approach for the classification of BdSL40 dataset. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on word-level BdSL recognition, and the dataset was transcribed from Indian Sign Language (ISL) using the Bangla Sign Language Dictionary (1997). The proposed GNN model achieved an F1 score of 89%. The study highlights the significant lexical and semantic similarity between BdSL, West Bengal Sign Language, and ISL, and the lack of word-level datasets for BdSLin the literature.

Status: AI for Bangla 2.0 winning solution!
